item.title: How to access Windows' OneDrive folder from Linux
item.description:
My friend had some files in the OneDrive folder on Windows’ partition, wondering how to access them directly from Linux (because of the unsupported reparse point error). Hence, this article was born.

  1. Install ntfs-3g (with FUSE support so you can mount drives without sudo).
  2. Download the plugin from Web Archive.
  3. Extract the zip and place the plugin (ntfs-plugin-9000001a.so in linux-64 or other platforms) under /usr/lib/ntfs-3g/. You might need to create the folder yourself.
  4. Mount the Windows partition with GUI or ntfs-3g /NTFS_partition /mount/point, e.g., ntfs-3g /dev/sda1 /mnt/windows. Unmount first if it has been mounted.
  5. If you want to mount the partition during boot, you can add /NTFS_partition /mount/point ntfs-3g defaults 0 0 to the end of your /etc/fstab.

References:

  • Bug #1728354 “ntfs: unsupported reparse point” : Bugs : ntfs-3g package : Ubuntu
  • AUR (en) - ntfs-3g-onedrive-bin

item.title: Distros to begin
item.description:
There are a lot of Linux distributions to choose from. Here are some distros I like and recommand to start with:

Debian/Ubuntu Based

  • Mint
  • Zorin OS

Arch Based

  • CachyOS

Why not Ubuntu?

Since Ubuntu 22.04, it directs apt install to Snap by default, which is forced by Canonical and might lead to broken or unexpected packages. The default desktop layout (vertical teskbar and Activities) can also be somewhat confusing to newcomers.

item.title: About
item.description:
Open Source advocate. Composer. Programmer. Pro-gamer. Likes Gamelan. Living somewhere around (24°N, 121°E) on earth.

Linux

Tried various distros since 2018, including Ubuntu, elementary OS, Linux Mint, Zorin OS, Ubuntu Studio, AV Linux, Feren OS, KDE neon, Regata OS, MX Linux, Nitrux, Manjaro, Arch Linux, Archcraft, Garuda Linux, Void Linux and openSUSE Thumbleweed.

Now live on CachyOS. I also recommend Zorin OS.

Music

Play the clarinet and the piano whilst mostly compose for concert band and piano. Mainly use Dorico for score, REAPER as DAW.
